awd_titl_txt: ISLS 2023: Building Knowledge and Sustaining Our Community: ISLS Doctoral Consortium and Early Career Workshops
awd_abstract_narration:
The United States has historically been a global leader in the field of the learning sciences, an interdisciplinary field that draws on multiple theoretical and methodological perspectives with the goal of advancing knowledge about human learning and development in a variety of educational settings, frequently in the context of emerging technologies. The preeminent conference in this field is the Annual Meeting of the International Society of the Learning Sciences (ISLS). At this conference the latest research is presented and practitioners learn the state of the art techniques in learning science research, and the related research area of computer-supported collaborative learning. 

The project provides partial travel support to the ISLS Meeting for six Ph.D. students from the United States, selected through a competitive process, to present their work and receive additional mentoring outside of their dissertation committees as part of a doctoral consortium. The project also supports partial travel support for five early career researchers from the United States, to discuss their research programs and career trajectories with peers and senior researchers in the field.  The intellectual merit of the work is in improving the dissertation research of the graduate students and building impact and opportunity for early career researchers; in both tracks the work is enhanced by guidance from world-class mentors who meet with the students in a structured format to improve their research. The broader impact includes multiplying opportunities to develop collaborations in the field of learning sciences, and supporting the career development of some of the best and brightest researchers in multiple disciplines who work in this interdisciplinary area. By supporting a pipeline of high-quality US scholars from multiple disciplines into this interdisciplinary field, this proposal helps ensure US participation and parity in this productive and vital area of research.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported costs associated with US-based graduate students and early career faculty to attend professional learning workshops at the 2023 International Conference of the Learning Sciences in Montreal, Canada (https://2023.isls.org/). The award supported conference registration costs, travel expenses, and meeting-related expenses for seven graduate students and five early career faculty from twelve different US IHEs. 

The two day pre-conferences professional learning workshops featured a range of presentations and working sessions focused on the development of dissertation and manuscript ideas, career mentoring, and work-life balance issues. Social time among both groups also helped to develop relationships among emerging scholars from universities across the US. 

A brief summary of the meeting agendas are below.

ISLS DOCTORAL CONSORTIUM SCHEDULE 2023

*Note: All meetings will take place at Dawson College 4001 de Maisonneuve West. 

Mentors

Daniel Boedemer, University of Duisburg-Essen

Xueqi Feng, Southern University of Science and Technology

Erica Rosenfeld Halverson, University of Wisconsin-Madison

Breanne Litts, Utah State University

Saturday Jun 10, 2023

13:00-15:00 “Representing the other” activity 

Meet in Room 3F.3

Pairs of people will work together and then we will come back as a whole group 

15:00-15:30 Break 

Atrium for coffee break

15:30-17:30 Small group work around conceptual framing and foundational research questions

We will work in 4 groups, led by mentors

Dinner - We will find a spot where we can all go if people want to go together


Sunday Jun 11, 2023

9:00-10:30 Planning the timing of your PhD thesis

Meet in Room 3F.3

Small groups with mentors

10:30-11:00 Break

Atrium for coffee break

11:00-12:30 5/3/1 minute pitch sessions

Honing research “pitch” from 5 minutes to 1 minute

12:30-13:30 Lunch break

Box lunch together in the atrium

13:30-14:30 Single slide presentation

We will work with the Mid-Career Workshop scholars to engage in shared presentations of our work

Meet in our room 3F.3

14:30-15:00 Break

15:00-17:00 Next steps for our group

Development of conference presentation groups, building future connections, etc.

Debrief from presentations

Logistics squared away

17:00-18:30 Journal Editor’s panel

Meet editors of LS/CSCL journals for presentations and question/answer sessions

Room 4C.1

19:30 Dinner at Place Carmin


The PI received a small stipend to support the organization of these meetings. As the granting institution, the University of Wisconsin-Madison received indirect costs to support the administration of the meetings.
